newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Media grill HK's Tung on rights, Taiwan, maids.
newsitem.headline: Media grill HK's Tung on rights, Taiwan, maids.

text.p: Hong Kong's new leader Tung Chee-hwa fielded questions from civil rights to the future of Filipina maids on Wednesday at his first news conference since the end of British rule.
Handpicked by Beijing for the job, Tung stressed capitalist Hong Kong's special autonomous status within China and said both sides needed to get to know each other better.
"Hong Kong has been separated from the motherland for some years," he said. "I don't think the people of Hong Kong know the motherland very well."

Hong Kong was reintegrated into China on Tuesday when more than 150 years of British rule ended. Under a 1984 accord, Hong Kong will be a Special Administrative Region (SAR) of China and its super-capitalist ways are to be left intact for 50 years.
Tung, a former shipping magnate, acknowledged that in the short term there would be conflicts with Beijing, which must be settled through dialogue.
But he stressed that the long-term interests of China and Hong Kong were the same.
"The more prosperous we are, the more we contribute to China's continued modernisation. The more prosperous China is, Hong Kong becomes even more prosperous," he said.
Tung was relaxed and jovial, casually answering an array of questions from hundreds of local and international journalists who packed the news conference hall.
He gracefully dodged tough questions and drew laughter with his quips as he shifted from English to Cantonese to Mandarin.
Tung was asked repeatedly about Hong Kong's soaring property market and what he intended to do to ensure that people would be able to afford housing.
"Property prices have been zooming up, which has a negative impact on the whole community," he said. "At the appropriate time, we will take resolute action."
But he could not be drawn on what that action might be and suggested it would be revealed in his economic policy statement in October.
Pressed on relations with nationalist Taiwan now that Hong Kong was part of China, Tung pledged dialogue and predicted the future of Taipei's official presence would be settled soon.
Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong is currently a travel agency.
Speaking the day after 10,000 people had demonstrated for democracy in Hong Kong on the first day of Chinese rule, Tung said protests would always be allowed.
"I have repeated many times that demonstrations so long as they are lawful and peaceful can go right ahead," Tung said.
But he made clear that he was uncomfortable with the idea of marching in the streets.
"Would I do it this way? Obviously not, because I think there are many channels open for good communication. I would have thought of a better way of communicating."
His one flash of anger came when he was asked if he would try to calm the waters between his administration and critics in the pro-democracy movement.
Tung noted the Democratic Party had pushed a string of laws through the elected colonial parliament before it was dissolved on Monday and replaced by a Beijing-appointed assembly.
"Each one of these laws, each one of these amendents, is being studied by the administration and we will do what is necessary to protect this community," he said.
Tung said he would visit the United States but that no date had been set and acknowledged that three of his children have U.S. passports, having been born in America.
Pressed on whether Hong Kong's 150,000-strong Filipino community -- the largest foreign group -- had anything to fear now that the territory was part of communist China, he said no.
"Filipino domestic help is very much a part of our community and hopefully will be for a long, long time to come," he said.
